title: muirfield-north-berwick-golf-courses-make-top-ten
story: North Berwick Golf Club and Muirfield, near Gullane, were highlighted by insurance provider SportsCover Direct.The firm analysed more than  courses across the globe, looking at heritage and public reviews – as well as cloud cover and annual rainfall.Royal Aberdeen Golf Clubtopped the list, with North Berwick Golf Club placed fourth and Muirfield ranked ninth.

title: celebrations-official-opening-300-000-rugby-club-upgrade
story: Councillor Andy Forrest, a Musselburgh councillor and depute provost of East Lothian, and Colin Rigby, vice-president of the Scottish Rugby Union, had the honour of cutting the ribbon to declare the new facilities open.Also present at the ceremony, ahead of the club’s match against Currie RFC, were project funders, supporters and club sponsors.The new facilities will also be available for other community groups to use, subject to the necessary agreements being in place.Drew Johnston, MRFC president, said: “Many people had ‘lockdown projects’ – ours was to build a new community gym facility and upgrade our changing rooms.“It has been a long and challenging journey but we are delighted with the end result.“As a flourishing organisation competing at the highest level in Scottish club rugby, it is vital we provide the best facilities possible – not only to develop our players across all ages and levels but also to strengthen our presence across the wider community, who we hope will also use these new facilities.“These new and upgraded facilities were designed to allow the club to fulfil our core values of integrity, respect and inclusion, and we look to the future with much confidence.“There are too many iniduals to thank but particular mention goes to ex-MRFC player Neil Smith who project-managed this for us.“We must of course thank and acknowledge our ious funders and supporters, not only for their backing but for their belief in what we are trying to achieve.“East Lothian Council, Musselburgh Common Good Fund, sportscotland, Scottish Rugby, Musselburgh Area Partnership and the Musselburgh Trust have all backed the project, and we are overwhelmed by their support.“Many of our members have also provided support and appear on our ‘wall of fame’ within the new facility.”East Lothian Provost John McMillan added: “I’d like to congratulate Musselburgh Rugby Football Club on the completion of this exciting project.“The new gym and upgraded changing room will be of real benefit to the club and its players, as well as the wider community. The club plays an important role in the local area and continues to go from strength to strength.“I’m delighted that East Lothian Council was able to provide important funding support from the Community Intervention Fund and the Musselburgh Common Good Fund.“I wish the club every success on and off the field and look forward to hearing about the positive impact the new and improved facilities have in terms of providing access and opportunities for the club and wider community.”Stewart Harris, chief executive of sportscotland, said: “It’s fantastic to see what has been achieved here by Musselburgh RFC.“Projects like this, which demonstrate real ambition and commitment to improving the lives of their communities through sport and physical activity, are a priority for sportscotland.“I am delighted that we were able to support this project with National Lottery investment, which will allow more people to participate in rugby and be part of this thriving community club.”David Drummond, Scottish Rugby East regional director, added: “Scottish Rugby is pleased to have supported this project and now see it come to le.“I’d like to commend the hard work of everyone at the club who have made this aspirational facility a reality.“This new environment will go a long way in nurturing players’ development, as well as providing means in which the club can connect with their local community, as they will be able to benefit from the space and facilities.”

title: charity-lunch-raises-1-500-laos-seamstresses
story: Organised by Musselburgh Inner Wheel Club, the event took place at St Michael’s Church Hall on Dalrymple Loan.“A huge thank you must go to everyone who attended this event for their support and generosity. The club was able to donate over £, to this wonderful charity,” said a club spokesperson.Each year, the club chooses an overseas charity to support and, this year, decided to aid Dignity, which was started by Andrew Hepburn to offer women in Laos the chance to start their own seamstress businesses.One of the projects under the auspices of Empathy International, Dignity runs a university offering tuition in sewing, pattern-making and fitting.This opportunity to upskill gives the girls and women a chance to earn a living without the fear of trafficking and enforced prostitution.Empathy does not give handouts but enables people to be self-sustaining. All money raised goes entirely to the project, with no running costs taken.

title: new-petrol-station-plans-given-green-light
story: The Motor Fuel Groupproposes to knock down the petrol station already there and replace it with “an enhanced roadside services offer” which will be open  hours a day as part of the redevelopment of Monktonhall Services.A drive-thru coffee shop is also earmarked for the site as part of a separate plan which has received the green light from the council.The former Travelodge building has been demolished and a new hotel is no longer planned, with the development having an increased focus on HGVs.Five HGV fuelling pumps will be located to the south of the site. There will be rest area for HGVs, complete with a shower and toilet block for drivers’ use.This facilities block will be formed from a former tourist information block on the site and a secure parking area will have space for up to  large vehicles.A new petrol filling station – including a retail kiosk and forecourt including six pumps, three jetwash bays, two air vac water bays and an ADBlue tank enclosed by .-metre-high galvanised metal palisade fencing and gates – is a key part of the plans.Eight charging points for electric vehicles will also be created and there will be  car parking spaces.There will also be a bin store, sheltered cycle parking and landscaping, and an internal road layout is planned at the site, which is located at the junction of the A, Edinburgh City Bypass and B.No public objections were raised to the application, which was decided by planners under the council’s scheme of delegated powers.Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council was consulted and did not respond, a planning report said.The document said that the development would provide “improved facilities to enhance the operation of an existing motorist’s service area”. The service area was an “established development and commercial use” within the East Lothian countryside, it added.The MFG previously said that,planning consent were granted, it was hoped the redevelopment would be completed this year.

title: man-caught-shouting-swearing-former-partner
story: James Givan also became involved in a physical struggle with his ex during the incident outside the Asda supermarket in Tranent.Givan pleaded guilty to an amended charge of behaving in a threatening or abusive manner when he appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Thursday.Fiscal depute Drew Long told the court that Givan turned up at the supermarket car park in May last year and, after seeing the woman with another man, he “lost his temper”.Mr Long said: “Mr Givan ran towards [his former partner] as she got out of the car.“He pushed her and there was a struggle and Mr Givan shouted at her and the man in the car.“He shouted and swore at both of them about how they were spending time together.”The court heard that the police were called to deal with Givan, of Pinkiehill Crescent, and he was arrested and charged.Mr Long said that -year-old Givan had abided by his bail conditions not to contact his ex-partner and that she did not want a non-harassment order to be imposed.Lawyer Angela Craig said her client had “unhappy experiences with relationships in the past” and he had “begun to have suspicions about [his former partner] seeing another man”.Ms Craig added that the woman had denied starting a new relationship and Givan had “lost his temper after seeing her in the car with another man”.The solicitor said that since the incident there had been “no repetition, no issues and he has no [criminal] record”.Sherf Roderick Flinn said that Givan had committed “a minor offence” and deferred sentence for him to be of good behaviour to June this year.The sherf said thatGivan stayed out of trouble until then, he would receive an admonition but,not, he would most likely be ordered to pay a fine.Givan pleaded guilty to behaving in a threatening or abusive manner by acting in an aggressive manner, shouting, swearing and struggling with his former partner at Asda, High Street, Tranent, on May  last year.

title: students-win-3-000-chosen-charity
story: Olivia Dale, Kirsty Dee and Ellen Davidson won Knox Academy’s Youth Philanthropy Initiativeevent at the beginning of the month.Five teams of pupils at the Haddington secondary school represented five charities at the final, with Muirfield Riding Therapy galloping to victory.Robert Flood, curriculum leader – social subjects, said: “There was The Wave Project, Muirfield Riding Therapy, Children st, The Bridges Project and Beyond Boundaries East Lothian.“There was a really high standard of presentation and the winning team was Muirfield Riding Therapy, who have won £, for that charity.”Muirfield Riding Therapy was formed in  in a muddy field with four borrowed ponies and a handful of hardy volunteers.Since then, the group has gone from strength to strength and has an indoor arena, complete with offices, a physiotherapy room, play area, meeting room and full- viewing gallery, at West Fenton, near Gullane.The charity provides pioneering, le-changing equine therapy.More than  teams started in the competition, which was then whittled down to the top five.Each of the finalists then had to make a presentation to a judging  made up of the school’s headteacher Sue Cook local councillor Shamin Akhtar Lesley Pirie, chair of the school’s parent council and Katie Moore, depute head pupil.Ms Cook said: “The research and presentation skills of all the finalists were extremely high.“They delivered passionately about the work of their charities, how they supported people and how £, would make a signicant dference to the continuation of their work.“Every single charity would have been a worthwhile winner however, there was only one cheque and therefore the judging  was versed with a very dficult decision!“After much deliberation, we selected Muirfield Riding Therapy to be this year’s recipients, after the team edged out the other ones with an outstanding question and answer session at the end of their presentation.“A huge congratulations to the winning team of Kirsty Dee, Ellen Davidson and Olivia Dale.“Well done to all teams who presented at all stages.“The standard was exceptional this year and the engagement with the chosen charities evident, even though the current pandemic presented some challenges that all of our young people worked around.”A Muirfield Riding Therapy statement on social media congratulated the trio.It read: “Well done and thank you so much Kirsty, Olivia and Ellen for your support.“Up against so many worthy causes.“Fantastic teamwork.”

title: zans-wildlife-diary-keep-lookout-kestrels
story: This species occupies a wide range of habitats it prefers open countryside but can also be seen in urban areas or at the edge of woodland.The kestrel is a medium-size bird that is slightly smaller than a feral pigeon. Males have a chestnut-brown back, light brown chest with black spots, and a prominent grey-blue head and tail, whilst females are unormly brown. Like most members of the falcon family, the kestrel is equipped with black eyes. The purpose of this is to reduce the amount of glare entering the bird’s eye and improves vision, especially in bright light.Kestrels are mostly distinguished by their typical hunting technique, hovering -m above the ground, either by flying into the wind and using its fanned tail and pointy wings to hold position, or by soaring using the lt caused by a ridge or a similar obstacle. The bird keeps its eyes constantly fixed on the ground and, when it eventually spots prey, it swoops down and kills using the side of the beak rather than using talons like hawks do.The kestrel’s hunting skills are enhanced by incredible eyesight. These birds can see ultraviolet colour that is invisible to the human eye! This means they can easily locate their prey by detecting a rodent’s urine trail, which shines brightly in ultraviolet.Apart from watching kestrels in the air, they can also be seen perched on a tree branch, fences, lampposts or wires.These birds mainly feed on field voles, which constitute most of their diet, but can also take mice, shrews, small birds and occasionally worms or large insects .Kestrels do not build nests but instead they lay eggs in natural cavities such as holes in trees or cracks in clfs. If you live in the countryside, a good way of encouraging kestrels to the area is to put up nest boxes for them. Each bird species has dferent requirements when it comes to nest boxes, so it is worth researching online as to what the right measurements should be. Feel free to get in touch with myself as well!With just a little bit of patience, kestrels can be easily spotted. Once you have learned their hover style, you will not mistake it for anything ! Another good tip for looking for kestrels is to remember that they are birds of habit –you saw them perched on a tree in the local park, try going there again at a similar time, there is a huge chance they will be around!In East Lothian, I have two favourite kestrel spots: one is in Musselburgh Lagoons and the other one at The Grove. I visit those places fairly frequently at dferent times of the day to give myself a greater chance of photographing the birds in dferent light, but it is worth remembering that birds are most active at dawn and dusk.So far, I have found kestrels surprisingly relaxed with my presence however, I would not feel confident to say whether all kestrels are like this orI have been lucky. The rule of the thumb is to remain respectful of an animal’s space and never to disturb them I always move slowly when taking steps towards an animal and never in a straight line, so it does not feel challenged. After each step, I remain in the same position for quite some time before taking a further step – this way an animal can get used to me and stops treating me as a threat. I always use this approach, no matter which animal I photograph.As spring is just around the corner and soon wildle will be in full swing, I wish you all good luck in wildle spotting!If you would like to share some wildle sightings with me or want to know more about kestrels, please get in touch:www.zanslenswww.facebook zanslenswww zans_lens

title: lothian-buses-x5-service-soon-return-east-lothian
story: Lothian Buses suspended the X service, which links North Berwick, Dirleton, Aberlady, Gullane and Longniddry with the capital, almost two years ago at the beginning of the coronavirus pandemic.Craig Hoy, South Scotland MSP, has repeatedly called in recent months for the service to be reinstated.He handed over a petition, which was signed by more than , people, calling for the service to be brought back to the bus company.Mr Hoy, who is also a councillor for the Haddington and Lammermuir ward on East Lothian Council, was pleased to say the bid for the service toseemed to be heading in the right direction.Nigel Serafini, the interim chief executive of Lothian Buses, wrote to the politician to update him on the situation.He said: “We are only just covering existing service levels but with an uplt of new recruits due to begin in the business shortly, we are hopeful that we will soon be in a position to announce a date for theof the service.“This does however critically hinge on no further outbreaks or changes to guidance in the coming weeks.“As always, we continue to review our network provision and remain committed to restoring services where circumstances allow.”In the absence of the X, people commuting into Edinburgh on the bus can face an extra hour being added on to their journey as they travel through Musselburgh and Portobello towards the city centre.In contrast, after passing through Longniddry, the X heads onto the A and into the capital.Mr Hoy welcomed the latest development and was keen to see further progress being made.He said: “I am pleased that Lothian Buses have now responded to the petition calling for the reinstatement of the X service, and I am delighted that they are looking at providing a date for theof the service ‘soon’.“The X bus was a popular service in the local community providing a direct and convenient route into the centre of Edinburgh in under an hour.”

title: new-kitchen-cliff-top-cafe-given-go-ahead-along-electric-bike-rental-firm-site
story: Drt cafe, east of North Berwick, was launched by husband-and-we Stuart and Jo McNicol, of adjacent Castleton Farm, in .And despite the Covid- pandemic, it has gone from strength to strength, welcoming thousands of visitors each year.Now the farm has been granted planning permission for  ‘modular buildings’ which will be used as a bakery for the cafe, as well creating farm offices and providing a home to an electric bike rental firm.Like Drt, e-bike company Ez-Riders has been described by planners as a farm ersication project which will generate new tourism and visitors to the area.Granting approval for the additional buildings in the farmyard, planning officers said that the application had received one objection from the Architectural Heritage Society of Scotland.Drt cafe has picturesque views of the Bass Rock from the clf edge. Image: Google MapsThe society said that the Tantallon Coast Statement of Importance described it as “the wildest, most remote and least developed area of mainland coast within East Lothian” and argued that the new units were incompatible with it.However, planning officers said that the units were being situated on an existing hard-surfaced yard area of the farm and supported a rural business.They said: “The modular buildings in use as a bakery are used as an additional food preparation facility and kitchen for the existing, established Drt cafe business which is located some  metres to the west of the site.“It is a popular tourism and leisure business and, due to its success, increased food preparation facilities are required.”And they said that the new units could lead to additional jobs being created.They added that an accompanying statement from the applicant had said that the additional bakery space at the farm would “secure existing employment and require three to four new full-time equivalent positions based at the farm".Additionally, planning officers ruled that the Ez-Riders start-up business fitted in to the tourism and leisure uses appropriate to the countryside and supported the Castleton Farm business.They said: “The use of the container units for Ez-Riders fits a farm ersication project whilst generating new tourism visitor-related business employment investment in the area.”Ez-riders was founded by North Berwick business partners Tina ORourke and Niall Middleton, the latter well-known for running the towns The Ship Inn for a decade until two years ago.

title: 300-people-sign-online-petition-remove-bird-netting-north-berwick-tesco
story: The supermarket brand has come under fire from members of the public after it was revealed that the netting was there to protect customers from bird droppings.House martin nests are protected by law and it is an offence to remove or interfere with them, but the netting at the store reduces available nesting space in the town.The online petition has now reached more than  signatures in  hours.It was set up by Carole Fairhurst, who believes that Tesco should remove the netting immediately.She said: "House martins and swallows are on the red list because theyve lost so many places that they can nest so they need to be protected."I think [Tesco] should remove it completely."The birds travel thousands of miles to come here, people should be thrilled that they are here, not trying to get rid of them.A similar incident occurred at a Tesco store in Norwich three years ago but the company backed down after backlash online.Members of the public in North Berwick have already shown their anger at the decision and shared their views online.One said: "What a short-sighted, parochial decision. There are more important things in the world than worrying about some endangered birds messing up your already unsightly supermarket."Another said: "What harm are they causing… absolutely none… the least a huge brand with a heavy carbon footprint can do is live and let live with nature."Wildle TV presenter and conservationist Chris Packham has also shared his views on Twitter.Hello @Tesco we’ve been here before haven’t we   Please fast track the solution which was to take down the nets , put up cameras and screens in the store and show your customers that you care about birds in the bioersity crisis we sadly find ourselves in . Thanks . Please RT https:t.co ayJxMrWSNy A Tesco spokesperson said: "The netting is in place as a safety and hygiene measure to prevent pigeons from accessing the roof space and dropping faeces onto the customer area below."We continue to monitor the measure with our teams."The petition can be signed at change.org p rspb-stop-the-netting-preventing-house-martin-s-nesting-at-north-berwick-tesco

title: 200-jobs-set-created-go-ahead-given-expansion-charles-river-laboratory-facilities
story: Charles River Laboratories have been given the go-ahead to expand the research and development buildings at their Elphinstone operation.The move will, the company says, create  fully qualied jobs equating to a  per cent rise in its local workforce.And it says it will increase capacity for all the work it does, including the safety and efficacy testing of vaccines, including Covid- vaccines.Geoff Burns, general manager, Charles River Edinburgh, said that plans were in place to open the new expansion later this year.He said: “We are very much looking forward to opening our brand-new facilities in autumn .“We are committed to attracting the best and the brightest in the industry, and we believe this latest investment, along with our minimum salary level increase, will help set us apart and cement Charles River Edinburgh as the best place to develop your career in le sciences.“Moreover, paying the real living wage shows our employees that we value their hard work and commitment. This is an exciting time to join Charles River Edinburgh.”Charles River Edinburgh general manager Geoff Burns with the companys director of human resources Linda Logan. Image courtesy of Charles RiverApplying for planning permission for the additional workspace, the firm, which has been operating on the site for more than  years, said that le sciences, in which it works, were hugely important to Scotland’s economy.It pointed out that more than , people worked in the sector across some  organisations.And it said that currently , staff worked at the Elphinstone site, with two-thirds of employees living in the county as well.It added: “The proposed development will allow for growth of another  full-time qualied posts, an increase of  per cent.”Approving the plans, which will see ,m of additional workspace added, including labs, offices and staff facilities, at the Elphinstone research centre, council planners said that there had been no public objections.An additional  car parking spaces will also be created and retrospective planning permission for a footpath which had been added to the site was also approved.

title: north-berwick-boys-progress-national-rugby-final-loretto-disqualified
story: Loretto won Saturdays encounter - but, following a complaint from North Berwick, the Scottish Rugby Unionhas expelled them from the competition.Ken Muir, head of youth rugby at North Berwick, said: "We believe that it was an innocent mistake."But because it was an overage player involved we thought it was necessary to appeal."The SRU has now confirmed that North Berwick will instead progress to next weeks final.Caitlin Gould, rugby development communications manager at the SRU said today: "Following on from the fixture at the weekend, a complaint was raised to the competitions team at Scottish Rugby as per the schools and youth rules and regulations."The committee, having met last night, made the decision to disqualy Loretto from the U Shield competition for a breach of the competition rules and regulations."A Loretto School spokesperson said: "On Saturday in the Shield Cup U semi-final, following a last-minute team change, Loretto School fielded a player outside the age banding. "This was a genuine oversight by the school and Loretto respects the decision of the SRU investigation. All at Loretto wish North Berwick every success in the final."Mr Muir was pleased for the North Berwick youngsters but also felt sorry for the Loretto players that will miss out.He said said: "Im delighted for the boys: theyll get their opportunity to play at Murrayfield in the final."We hold nothing against Loretto, nor the player involved, but having overage players can cause serious incidents in age-group rugby."North Berwick High School will now play Queen Victoria School, from Dunblane, in the final next Wednesdayat .pm at the DAM Health Stadium, the new home of Edinburgh Rugby, adjacent to Murrayfield Stadium.

title: paul-gascoigne-footballer-join-prestonpans-dinner-event
story: An Evening with Paul Gascoigne, at the Royal Musselburgh Golf Club, will take place on March  pm.Fans will enjoy a Sunday roast lunch, meet and greet and a live interview with a QA session to conclude.Tickets cost £ per person, or £ for a table of nine.For more information, contact Barry Brock on  or via email at bbcarpetcleaning@yahoo

title: fly-tippers-slammed-dumping-rubbish-port-seton
story: Cockenzie  Port Seton Community Council noted that numerous televisions, bags of clothing, children’s toys and games – and even cash – were cleared from the Co-op’s additional car park in one morning.The suspected tipper will be contacted by a community council member after several pieces of correspondence addressed to the same person were found in the bags.A community council spokesperson said: “Please help us look after our beautul village by disposing of rubbish safely and legally.”They encouraged residents to report fly-tipping when andthey saw it.A special thanks was made to Jim, from Links Road Garage, for clearing the rubbish.

title: north-berwick-charity-shop-crucial-saving-lives-says-local-msp
story: Craig Hoy, South Scotland MSP, recently visited the British Heart Foundationshop in North Berwick, and encouraged more residents to volunteer and help save lives across the county.He said: “I had a very informative discussion with Patricia and Jonathan about the impact the British Heart Foundation has on people’s lives throughout Scotland.“I also learned more about the positive experience of volunteering. As well as helping good causes like the BHF, it is a great opportunity to meet new people, gain new skills and help the environment by giving unwanted items a new lease of le.“I’d like to thank our local volunteers for all they do supporting heart and circulatory disease research in our community and would encourage others to think about volunteering too.”Heart disease kills nearly  people a day in Scotland and affects about , people nationwide.The BHF is the largest independent funder of heart and circulatory research but relies on public donations to achieve its goals.Jonathan Roden, BHF Scotland’s policy and public affairs manager, said: “It goes without saying that volunteers are the leblood of our shops. Every hour donated makes a dference. It helps us raise money to power le-saving science to save and improve lives.“Across Scotland around , people are living with heart and circulatory diseases. Your gt of time can help us help them. “For more than  years, your support has helped the BHF turn research that once seemed like ‘science fiction’ into reality and we need your help now more than ever.”

title: nurserys-youngsters-joy-book-donation
story: Miller Homes, which is set to build  new homes on land off Whitecraig Road, has donated £ and new books to aid the nursery’s  reading programme.Development sales manager Kristi Brimer joined the children at the nursery to drop off the donation and books.Claire Graham, acting headteacher at Whitecraig Primary School, which includes the nursery, said: “The donation of £ plus new books to our nursery group is really appreciated and we are delighted that Miller Homes has contributed such fantastic reads for our children.“We are sure that the nursery kids will have great fun with the books during our  reading programme.”Lynsey Brown, regional sales director for Miller Homes, added: “We’re thrilled to provide new reading material that will help the children discover a love for books as they prepare to move up to school.“Many of the families that move to the Carberry Grange development will have young children who will attend this nursery, so we are delighted to be able to support them with this donation.”For more information on Miller Homes or the development at Carberry Grange, visit millerhomes

title: musselburgh-businessman-backs-bid-save-nations-fish-chip-shops
story: Carlo Crolla, , owner of East Coast Fish  Chips and East Coast Restaurant on North High Street, has teamed up with the National Federation of Fish Friersto help prevent up to a third of the country’s fish and chip shops from disappearing from high streets.Mr Crolla says the price of fish has doubled, energy bills have spiralled, and cooking oil is more expensive than ever. As a result, some of the nation’s fish and chip shops are now struggling for survival.As they are not protected by the energy price cap, chip shops are now facing huge rises in energy costs. Some members of NFFF have reported electricity bills going up from £ to £, a month.The NFFF is urging the government to reconsider its planned  per cent increase on VAT in April, which is an added concern for the industry.The spiralling costs hitting fish and chip shops include a  per cent rise in the cost of cod since October,  per cent rise in the cost of haddock in the last year,  per cent rise in the cost of mushy peas, and  per cent rise in the cost of batter.Industry leaders now say that chip shops will have to raise prices to survive but many could be forced out of business.In , East Coast was crowned one of the UK’s  Best Fish  Chip Takeaways for the second year running – the only chippy in Edinburgh and the Lothians to make the list.The accolade followed an extensive search by trade publication Fry Magazine to find the chippies serving up the finest fish suppers amid the ongoing challenges of the Covid- pandemic.Mr Crolla runs the Musselburgh takeaway and restaurant with his we Katia, and his family have been serving the local community for nearly  years.He said: “By teaming up with the National Federation of Fish Friers we hope to do our bit by encouraging people to support their local fish and chip shop around Scotland during these extremely challenging times.“Our family has been proudly serving the local community with quality fish and chips for nearly  years, but the spiralling costs battering our industry are putting all that at risk.“We won’t compromise on quality, but these external factors will inevitably mean a rise in costs for us and our customers.”Andrew Crook, president of the NFFF, added: “We are in unprecedented times where we are seeing high levels of inflation, and food inflation is even higher.“Most of the supplies we use in the fish and chip industry have increased drastically in price and we are expecting this to continue for some considerable time.“Other products are simply not available, and we have seen suppliers move away from the sector.“Fish and chip shops like East Coast in Musselburgh do feel the effect of these increases more than most cuisines as our margins are much tighter. The price of fish is comparable to steak in supermarkets.“As a result of this, and our commitment to ensuring a high-quality, good-value product, we may regrettably be forced to review our prices to reflect the rising costs our industry is facing.”

title: mothers-day-chocolate-gifts-can-buy-year-including-hotel-chocolat
